cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
The bones of King Richard III have been discovered under a car park in which English city?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: King Richard III was a historical figure whose remains were famously discovered in 2012. The search for his burial site was conducted in various locations, but it ultimately led to the discovery of his bones beneath a car park. This significant archaeological find took place in the city known for its historical connection to Richard III and the Wars of the Roses.

Answer: Leicester

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
The bones of King Richard III have been discovered under a car park in which English city?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- The remains of King Richard III are discovered beneath a Council car park. Plans are begun for his eventual reinterment in Leicester Cathedral.\n', 'King Richard III Visitor Centre is an establishment in Leicester, England, that showcases the life of King Richard III and the story of how his remains were discovered in 2012. The centre opened in 2014 on the site of Greyfriars, the medieval friary in whose church the King was buried.\n', 'The location of Richard III\'s body has long been of interest to the members of the Richard III Society, a group established to bring about a reappraisal of the King\'s tarnished reputation. In 1975 an article by Audrey Strange was published in the society\'s journal, "The Ricardian", suggesting that his remains were buried under Leicester City Council\'s car park. The claim was repeated in 1986, when historian David Baldwin suggested that the remains were still in the Greyfriars area. He speculated, "It is possible (though now perhaps unlikely) that at some time in the twenty-first century an excavator may yet reveal the slight remains of this famous monarch."\n', 'Britain’s kings appear to be making a habit of this. First it was Richard III, whose bones were found under a car park in Leicester. Now it appears that Henry I may have met a similarly undignified fate.\n', 'On 12 September 2012 archaeologists announced the discovery of a buried skeleton with spinal abnormalities and head injuries under a car park in Leicester, and their suspicions that it might be Richard III. On 4 February 2013, it was announced that DNA testing had convinced Leicester University scientists and researchers "beyond reasonable doubt" that the remains were those of King Richard. On 26 March 2015, these remains were ceremonially buried in Leicester Cathedral On the following day Richard\'s tomb was unveiled.\n', 'Following the discovery of the remains of King Richard III in 2012, Mount Saint Bernard Abbey was proposed as a suitable place for his bones to be housed until agreement could be reached on a permanent resting place. Members of the \'Looking For Richard\' team, headed by Philippa Langley claimed that the University of Leicester had agreed to release the remains once scientific testing had been finished, so that they might be placed in a "prayerful environment", prior to reburial. A Catholic site was felt to be particularly appropriate since Richard had been a pre-Reformation (and thereby Catholic) monarch, and had originally been laid to rest in the monastic church of Greyfriars, Leicester. In 2014, Dr John Ashdown-Hill, genealogist with Langley\'s team, told the Leicester Mercury, "The site originally proposed for this was Mount St Bernard\'s Abbey, which is not far from Leicester. This would be a very suitable place for King Richard to lie in peace, surrounded by the prayers of the monks, pending his reinterment." The University however claimed that this agreement had not been legally binding and declined to release the king\'s remains, which were finally reinterred in the Anglican Cathedral of Leicester, on 26 March 2015. The monks of Saint Bernard reacted impartially to the dispute and when contacted by the Mercury newspaper, a spokesperson said it was felt that the community was not in a position to comment on the situation.\n', "Richard's corpse was taken to the nearby town of Leicester and buried without pomp. His original tomb monument is believed to have been removed during the English Reformation, and his remains were lost, as they were believed to have been thrown into the River Soar. In 2012, an archaeological excavation was commissioned by the Richard III Society on the site previously occupied by Greyfriars Priory Church. The University of Leicester identified the skeleton found in the excavation as that of Richard III as a result of radiocarbon dating, comparison with contemporary reports of his appearance, and comparison of his mitochondrial DNA with that of two matrilineal descendants of Richard III's eldest sister, Anne of York. He was reburied in Leicester Cathedral on 26 March 2015.\n", "In August 2012, after three years of work persuading the authorities in Leicester, the search for the lost remains of Richard III began with the excavation of the Social Services Department car park. On the first day of the dig (25 August 2012) bones which proved to be those of Richard III were found in the area predicted by Ashdown-Hill and Langley. Subsequent DNA research proved that the mtDNA of the bones matched the sequence from Richard III's descendants that Ashdown-Hill had discovered in 2004.\n", "A cenotaph memorial stone to Richard III was until recently located in the chancel; it was replaced by the tomb of the king himself. The monarch, killed in 1485 at the Leicestershire battlefield of Bosworth Field, had been roughly interred in the Greyfriars, Leicester. His remains were exhumed from the Greyfriars site in 2012 and publicly identified in February 2013. Peter Soulsby, Mayor of Leicester, and David Monteith, the cathedral's canon chancellor, announced the king's body would be reinterred in Leicester Cathedral in 2015. This was carried out on 26 March.\n", 'The body of King Richard III was sometimes said to have been thrown into the river during the Dissolution of the Monasteries under Henry VIII. From this legend, the bridge carrying the A47 across the Soar at Leicester is known as "King Richard\'s Bridge". However, in 2013, it was confirmed that the skeleton discovered beneath a car park in 2012 was, in fact, that of Richard III and, in March 2015, the skeleton was re-interred in Leicester Cathedral.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To address the question regarding the discovery of King Richard III's bones, we can extract and analyze several key pieces of content from the provided passages. This content will help provide context and background that may not be familiar to the model, enhancing its understanding of the historical and archaeological significance of the discovery.

### Extracted Content:

1. **Location of Discovery**:
   - "The remains of King Richard III are discovered beneath a Council car park."
   - "On 12 September 2012 archaeologists announced the discovery of a buried skeleton with spinal abnormalities and head injuries under a car park in Leicester."
   - "In August 2012, after three years of work persuading the authorities in Leicester, the search for the lost remains of Richard III began with the excavation of the Social Services Department car park."

   **Role**: This information establishes the specific location (Leicester) and the unusual setting (a car park) where the remains were found, highlighting the unexpected nature of the discovery.

2. **Historical Context**:
   - "The monarch, killed in 1485 at the Leicestershire battlefield of Bosworth Field, had been roughly interred in the Greyfriars, Leicester."
   - "His original tomb monument is believed to have been removed during the English Reformation, and his remains were lost, as they were believed to have been thrown into the River Soar."

   **Role**: This content provides historical context about King Richard III, including his death and the subsequent loss of his remains. Understanding the historical backdrop is crucial for appreciating the significance of the discovery.

3. **Scientific Validation**:
   - "Subsequent DNA research proved that the mtDNA of the bones matched the sequence from Richard III's descendants."
   - "On 4 February 2013, it was announced that DNA testing had convinced Leicester University scientists and researchers 'beyond reasonable doubt' that the remains were those of King Richard."

   **Role**: This information highlights the scientific methods used to confirm the identity of the remains, emphasizing the role of modern archaeology and genetics in historical research. It underscores the importance of scientific validation in historical claims.

4. **Reinterment**:
   - "On 26 March 2015, these remains were ceremonially buried in Leicester Cathedral."
   - "The University however claimed that this agreement had not been legally binding and declined to release the king's remains, which were finally reinterred in the Anglican Cathedral of Leicester."

   **Role**: This content discusses the eventual reinterment of Richard III's remains, which is significant for understanding the cultural and religious implications of his burial. It reflects on the ongoing debates about historical figures' legacies and their final resting places.

5. **Cultural Impact**:
   - "The King Richard III Visitor Centre is an establishment in Leicester, England, that showcases the life of King Richard III and the story of how his remains were discovered in 2012."
   - "The location of Richard III's body has long been of interest to the members of the Richard III Society, a group established to bring about a reappraisal of the King's tarnished reputation."

   **Role**: This information illustrates the cultural and societal interest in Richard III, including the efforts of organizations to rehabilitate his image. It shows how historical discoveries can influence public perception and cultural heritage.

### Analysis of the Role of Extracted Content:

The extracted content serves multiple purposes:

- **Contextualization**: It provides essential historical and archaeological context that enriches the understanding of the significance of the discovery.
- **Scientific Insight**: It emphasizes the role of scientific methods in confirming historical identities, which is crucial for modern historical scholarship.
- **Cultural Relevance**: It highlights the ongoing societal interest in Richard III, reflecting how historical figures continue to impact contemporary culture and identity.
- **Narrative Development**: It helps construct a narrative around the life, death, and rediscovery of Richard III, making the historical figure more relatable and significant to modern audiences.

By integrating this background knowledge, the model can better understand the implications of the discovery of King Richard III's remains and respond more effectively to related questions.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.

The bones of King Richard III have been discovered under a car park in which English city?

Reasoning process: King Richard III was a historical figure whose remains were famously discovered in 2012. The search for his burial site was conducted in various locations, but it ultimately led to the discovery of his bones beneath a car park. This significant archaeological find took place in the city known for its historical connection to Richard III and the Wars of the Roses.

Answer: Leicester

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question regarding the discovery of King Richard III's bones, we can enhance the reasoning process by integrating relevant background knowledge from the retrieved passages. This will provide a more comprehensive understanding of the historical, archaeological, and cultural significance of the discovery.

1. **Historical Background**:
   - King Richard III was a monarch who ruled from 1483 until his death in 1485 at the Battle of Bosworth Field, a pivotal event in the Wars of the Roses. His reign and subsequent death marked the end of the Plantagenet dynasty and the rise of the Tudor dynasty.
   - After his death, Richard's body was hastily buried in the Greyfriars Church in Leicester. Over the centuries, the exact location of his remains became a mystery, with various theories suggesting they had been lost or destroyed during the English Reformation.

2. **Discovery Context**:
   - The search for Richard III's remains began in earnest in 2012, led by the Richard III Society and archaeologists from the University of Leicester. The excavation took place beneath a car park, which was previously the site of Greyfriars Church.
   - On September 12, 2012, archaeologists announced the discovery of a skeleton with distinctive spinal abnormalities and head injuries consistent with historical accounts of Richard III's appearance and injuries sustained in battle.

3. **Scientific Validation**:
   - The identification of the remains was confirmed through advanced scientific methods, including DNA analysis that matched the mitochondrial DNA of the skeleton with living descendants of Richard III's family. This scientific validation was crucial in establishing the authenticity of the remains.

4. **Cultural and Societal Impact**:
   - The discovery of Richard III's remains sparked significant public interest and debate about his legacy. The King Richard III Visitor Centre was established in Leicester to educate the public about his life and the circumstances surrounding his death and burial.
   - The reinterment of Richard III's remains in Leicester Cathedral on March 26, 2015, was a significant event, reflecting the ongoing interest in his historical narrative and the efforts to rehabilitate his reputation.

5. **Conclusion**:
   - The discovery of King Richard III's bones beneath a car park in Leicester not only resolved a historical mystery but also reignited discussions about his life, reign, and the events that led to his downfall. It serves as a reminder of how archaeology can illuminate our understanding of history and influence contemporary cultural identity.

### Answer:
Leicester

1. **Discovery Location**: The remains of King Richard III were discovered beneath a car park in Leicester, England, specifically under a Council car park. This discovery was made in 2012 during an archaeological excavation initiated by the Richard III Society.

2. **Historical Context**: Richard III, who reigned from 1483 until his death in 1485, was killed at the Battle of Bosworth Field. Following his death, his body was hastily buried in the Greyfriars Priory Church in Leicester, and over time, the exact location of his remains became lost to history.

3. **Identification of Remains**: The skeleton found during the excavation exhibited spinal abnormalities and head injuries consistent with historical accounts of Richard III's death. DNA testing confirmed the identity of the remains, matching mitochondrial DNA with that of living descendants of Richard III's sister.

4. **Reinterment**: After the identification of the remains, there was a significant public and scholarly interest in reinterring Richard III in a dignified manner. His remains were eventually reburied in Leicester Cathedral on March 26, 2015, after a ceremonial service.

5. **Cultural and Historical Significance**: The discovery and reburial of Richard III have sparked renewed interest in his life and legacy, as well as discussions about the historical narrative surrounding his reign. The King Richard III Visitor Centre in Leicester serves as a focal point for this interest, showcasing the history and the story of the discovery.

6. **Public and Scholarly Engagement**: The excavation and subsequent findings were the result of years of advocacy by members of the Richard III Society and other historians, highlighting the intersection of public interest, historical research, and archaeological practice.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

The question asks about the location of King Richard III's remains, which were discovered under a car park. To answer this question accurately, it is essential to consider both the historical context and the significance of the discovery.

1. **Historical Context**: King Richard III was a monarch of England who reigned from 1483 until his death in 1485 at the Battle of Bosworth Field, a pivotal event in the Wars of the Roses. After his death, his body was hastily buried in Greyfriars Priory in Leicester. Over the centuries, the exact location of his burial became uncertain, leading to various theories about where his remains might be found.

2. **Discovery of Remains**: In 2012, an archaeological excavation was conducted in Leicester, specifically targeting a site believed to be the former location of Greyfriars Priory. This excavation was initiated by the Richard III Society, which had long sought to locate the king's remains. The discovery of a skeleton with distinct spinal abnormalities and head injuries, consistent with historical accounts of Richard III, was a significant breakthrough.

3. **Identification Process**: The identification of the remains was confirmed through DNA testing, which matched the mitochondrial DNA of the skeleton with that of living descendants of Richard III's sister. This scientific validation was crucial in establishing the authenticity of the remains.

4. **Reinterment and Cultural Significance**: Following the identification, there was considerable public interest in reinterring Richard III in a manner befitting a king. His remains were ceremonially reburied in Leicester Cathedral on March 26, 2015. This event not only marked the conclusion of a historical mystery but also reignited discussions about Richard III's legacy and the historical narratives surrounding his reign.

5. **Public Engagement and Legacy**: The discovery and reburial of Richard III have had a lasting impact on historical scholarship and public interest in medieval history. The King Richard III Visitor Centre in Leicester serves as a testament to this renewed interest, providing educational resources and insights into the life and times of Richard III.

By synthesizing this information, we gain a deeper understanding of the significance of the discovery of Richard III's remains in Leicester. It highlights the intersection of archaeology, history, and public interest, illustrating how modern methods can illuminate historical narratives and contribute to our understanding of the past.

### Answer:
Leicester

Members of the 'Looking For Richard' team, headed by Philippa Langley claimed that the University of Leicester had agreed to release the remains once scientific testing had been finished, so that they might be placed in a "prayerful environment", prior to reburial. A Catholic site was felt to be particularly appropriate since Richard had been a pre-Reformation (and thereby Catholic) monarch, and had originally been laid to rest in the monastic church of Greyfriars, Leicester. In 2014, Dr John Ashdown-Hill, genealogist with Langley's team, told the Leicester Mercury, "The site originally proposed for this was Mount St Bernard's Abbey, which is not far from Leicester. This would be a very suitable place for King Richard to lie in peace, surrounded by the prayers of the monks, pending his reinterment." The University however claimed that this agreement had not been legally binding and declined to release the king's remains, which were finally reinterred in the Anglican Cathedral of Leicester, on 26 March 2015. The monks of Saint Bernard reacted impartially to the dispute and when contacted by the Mercury newspaper, a spokesperson said it was felt that the community was not in a position to comment on the situation.
', "Richard's corpse was taken to the nearby town of Leicester and buried without pomp. His original tomb monument is believed to have been removed during the English Reformation, and his remains were lost, as they were believed to have been thrown into the River Soar. In 2012, an archaeological excavation was commissioned by the Richard III Society on the site previously occupied by Greyfriars Priory Church. The University of Leicester identified the skeleton found in the excavation as that of Richard III as a result of radiocarbon dating, comparison with contemporary reports of his appearance, and comparison of his mitochondrial DNA with that of two matrilineal descendants of Richard III's eldest sister, Anne of York. He was reburied in Leicester Cathedral on 26 March 2015.
", "In August 2012, after three years of work persuading the authorities in Leicester, the search for the lost remains of Richard III began with the excavation of the Social Services Department car park. On the first day of the dig (25 August 2012) bones which proved to be those of Richard III were found in the area predicted by Ashdown-Hill and Langley. Subsequent DNA research proved that the mtDNA of the bones matched the sequence from Richard III's descendants that Ashdown-Hill had discovered in 2004.
", "A cenotaph memorial stone to Richard III was until recently located in the chancel; it was replaced by the tomb of the king himself. The monarch, killed in 1485 at the Leicestershire battlefield of Bosworth Field, had been roughly interred in the Greyfriars, Leicester. His remains were exhumed from the Greyfriars site in 2012 and publicly identified in February 2013. Peter Soulsby, Mayor of Leicester, and David Monteith, the cathedral's canon chancellor, announced the king's body would be reinterred in Leicester Cathedral in 2015. This was carried out on 26 March.
", 'The body of King Richard III was sometimes said to have been thrown into the river during the Dissolution of the Monasteries under Henry VIII. From this legend, the bridge carrying the A47 across the Soar at Leicester is known as "King Richard's Bridge". However, in 2013, it was confirmed that the skeleton discovered beneath a car park in 2012 was, in fact, that of Richard III and, in March 2015, the skeleton was re-interred in Leicester Cathedral.
']

Task Description:

consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate key information from the provided passages regarding the discovery of King Richard III's remains. Here’s a summary of the relevant content:

### Consolidated Information:

1. **Discovery Location**: The remains of King Richard III were discovered beneath a car park in Leicester, England. This was confirmed by archaeologists on 12 September 2012.

2. **Historical Context**: Richard III was killed in 1485 at the Battle of Bosworth Field and was originally buried in Greyfriars, Leicester. His burial site was lost over time, leading to speculation about his remains' location.

3. **Identification of Remains**: The skeleton found was identified as Richard III through various methods, including radiocarbon dating, analysis of physical abnormalities (such as spinal issues), and DNA comparison with living descendants.

4. **Reinterment**: After identification, Richard III's remains were reinterred in Leicester Cathedral on 26 March 2015, following a public ceremony.

5. **Public Interest and Societal Impact**: The discovery sparked significant interest from historians and the public, leading to the establishment of the King Richard III Visitor Centre in Leicester, which educates visitors about his life and the discovery process.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Cause and Effect**: The passages illustrate a clear cause-and-effect relationship: the archaeological excavation (cause) led to the discovery of Richard III's remains (effect). This helps the model understand how actions can lead to specific outcomes.

2. **Historical Contextualization**: By providing background on Richard III's life, death, and burial, the model can better grasp the significance of the discovery. This contextual knowledge aids in making logical connections between historical events and their implications.

3. **Methodological Rigor**: The identification of the remains through scientific methods (radiocarbon dating, DNA analysis) emphasizes the importance of evidence-based reasoning. This can enhance the model's ability to evaluate claims based on the strength of evidence presented.

4. **Public Engagement**: The establishment of the visitor center and public interest highlights how discoveries can influence societal perceptions and historical narratives. Understanding this dynamic can improve the model's reasoning about the broader implications of historical events.

5. **Temporal Sequencing**: The timeline of events—from the initial excavation to the reinterment—provides a clear sequence that the model can use to understand temporal relationships and the progression of events over time.

### Conclusion:

By consolidating and analyzing the extracted information, the model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. The emphasis on cause-and-effect relationships, the importance of contextual knowledge, the role of scientific methods, and the impact of societal engagement all contribute to a more nuanced understanding of historical events. This, in turn, enhances the model's ability to reason logically about complex scenarios and draw informed conclusions based on available evidence.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.
question:
The bones of King Richard III have been discovered under a car park in which English city?
answer:
Reasoning process: King Richard III was a historical figure whose remains were famously discovered in 2012. The search for his burial site was conducted in various locations, but it ultimately led to the discovery of his bones beneath a car park. This significant archaeological find took place in the city known for its historical connection to Richard III and the Wars of the Roses.

Answer: Leicester

Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

King Richard III, a significant historical figure, was the last king of the House of York and the last of the Plantagenet dynasty. His remains were famously discovered in 2012 beneath a car park in Leicester, England. The search for his burial site was initiated by the Richard III Society, which aimed to locate his lost remains and reappraise his historical reputation. 

The discovery was officially announced on 12 September 2012, when archaeologists uncovered a skeleton with distinct spinal abnormalities and head injuries, which matched descriptions of Richard III. Subsequent DNA testing confirmed the identity of the remains, providing strong evidence that they belonged to the king. This was reported on 4 February 2013, when Leicester University scientists stated they were "beyond reasonable doubt" that the remains were those of Richard III.

The site of the discovery was historically significant, as it was located in the area previously occupied by Greyfriars Priory Church, where Richard III was originally buried after his death in 1485. Following the identification of the remains, they were ceremonially reinterred in Leicester Cathedral on 26 March 2015, marking a significant moment in both historical and archaeological contexts.

This enhanced reasoning process incorporates details about the historical significance of the site, the identity confirmation through DNA testing, and the public interest surrounding the discovery, which collectively provide a comprehensive understanding of the event.

**Answer:**
Leicester

question_info.question: The bones of King Richard III have been discovered under a car park in which English city?
passages:
BULLET::::- The remains of King Richard III are discovered beneath a Council car park. Plans are begun for his eventual reinterment in Leicester Cathedral.
King Richard III Visitor Centre is an establishment in Leicester, England, that showcases the life of King Richard III and the story of how his remains were discovered in 2012. The centre opened in 2014 on the site of Greyfriars, the medieval friary in whose church the King was buried.
The location of Richard III's body has long been of interest to the members of the Richard III Society, a group established to bring about a reappraisal of the King's tarnished reputation. In 1975 an article by Audrey Strange was published in the society's journal, "The Ricardian", suggesting that his remains were buried under Leicester City Council's car park. The claim was repeated in 1986, when historian David Baldwin suggested that the remains were still in the Greyfriars area. He speculated, "It is possible (though now perhaps unlikely) that at some time in the twenty-first century an excavator may yet reveal the slight remains of this famous monarch."
Britain’s kings appear to be making a habit of this. First it was Richard III, whose bones were found under a car park in Leicester. Now it appears that Henry I may have met a similarly undignified fate.
On 12 September 2012 archaeologists announced the discovery of a buried skeleton with spinal abnormalities and head injuries under a car park in Leicester, and their suspicions that it might be Richard III. On 4 February 2013, it was announced that DNA testing had convinced Leicester University scientists and researchers "beyond reasonable doubt" that the remains were those of King Richard. On 26 March 2015, these remains were ceremonially buried in Leicester Cathedral On the following day Richard's tomb was unveiled.
Following the discovery of the remains of King Richard III in 2012, Mount Saint Bernard Abbey was proposed as a suitable place for his bones to be housed until agreement could be reached on a permanent resting place. Members of the 'Looking For Richard' team, headed by Philippa Langley claimed that the University of Leicester had agreed to release the remains once scientific testing had been finished, so that they might be placed in a "prayerful environment", prior to reburial. A Catholic site was felt to be particularly appropriate since Richard had been a pre-Reformation (and thereby Catholic) monarch, and had originally been laid to rest in the monastic church of Greyfriars, Leicester. In 2014, Dr John Ashdown-Hill, genealogist with Langley's team, told the Leicester Mercury, "The site originally proposed for this was Mount St Bernard's Abbey, which is not far from Leicester. This would be a very suitable place for King Richard to lie in peace, surrounded by the prayers of the monks, pending his reinterment." The University however claimed that this agreement had not been legally binding and declined to release the king's remains, which were finally reinterred in the Anglican Cathedral of Leicester, on 26 March 2015. The monks of Saint Bernard reacted impartially to the dispute and when contacted by the Mercury newspaper, a spokesperson said it was felt that the community was not in a position to comment on the situation.
Richard's corpse was taken to the nearby town of Leicester and buried without pomp. His original tomb monument is believed to have been removed during the English Reformation, and his remains were lost, as they were believed to have been thrown into the River Soar. In 2012, an archaeological excavation was commissioned by the Richard III Society on the site previously occupied by Greyfriars Priory Church. The University of Leicester identified the skeleton found in the excavation as that of Richard III as a result of radiocarbon dating, comparison with contemporary reports of his appearance, and comparison of his mitochondrial DNA with that of two matrilineal descendants of Richard III's eldest sister, Anne of York. He was reburied in Leicester Cathedral on 26 March 2015.
In August 2012, after three years of work persuading the authorities in Leicester, the search for the lost remains of Richard III began with the excavation of the Social Services Department car park. On the first day of the dig (25 August 2012) bones which proved to be those of Richard III were found in the area predicted by Ashdown-Hill and Langley. Subsequent DNA research proved that the mtDNA of the bones matched the sequence from Richard III's descendants that Ashdown-Hill had discovered in 2004.
A cenotaph memorial stone to Richard III was until recently located in the chancel; it was replaced by the tomb of the king himself. The monarch, killed in 1485 at the Leicestershire battlefield of Bosworth Field, had been roughly interred in the Greyfriars, Leicester. His remains were exhumed from the Greyfriars site in 2012 and publicly identified in February 2013. Peter Soulsby, Mayor of Leicester, and David Monteith, the cathedral's canon chancellor, announced the king's body would be reinterred in Leicester Cathedral in 2015. This was carried out on 26 March.
The body of King Richard III was sometimes said to have been thrown into the river during the Dissolution of the Monasteries under Henry VIII. From this legend, the bridge carrying the A47 across the Soar at Leicester is known as "King Richard's Bridge". However, in 2013, it was confirmed that the skeleton discovered beneath a car park in 2012 was, in fact, that of Richard III and, in March 2015, the skeleton was re-interred in Leicester Cathedral.
